title: Corrections: April 19, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 19, 2020.
content: An article last Sunday about the FX series “Mrs. America” misstated the publication status of the historian Rick Perlstein’s book “The Invisible Bridge: The Fall of Nixon and the Rise of Reagan.” It has been published; it is not forthcoming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: When Pet Owners Fall Ill With Coronavirus, What Happens Next?
description: Spain, which is enduring one of the world’s biggest and deadliest outbreaks, grapples with moral and practical questions on caring for animals when their owners are suddenly sick.
content: MADRID — The coronavirus strikes. The patient — at home, sometimes alone — becomes desperately ill. The ambulance finally arrives to take the person away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jolie Kerr
title: How to Tame Common Childhood Plagues
description: Lice, pinkeye and pinworm can spread easily from child to household, but thorough cleaning and good hygiene can help fight them off.
content: This article was originally published on June 3, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Missing Boston, and a Bus Ride, on Marathon Day
description: There is nothing like the Boston Marathon. Patriots’ Day without the race, and that magical trip to the start line, feels empty.
content: Everyone who has run the Boston Marathon has a favorite moment of the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Nobuhiko Obayashi, Unpredictable Japanese Director, Dies at 82
description: He made a splash in 1977 with a horror movie about a  house full of furniture that eats schoolgirls. His later movies explored a range of themes.
content: Nobuhiko Obayashi, an idiosyncratic Japanese filmmaker whose wide-ranging résumé included a horror movie about a house full of furniture that eats schoolgirls, a fantasy about a boy who befriends a six-inch-tall samurai and an antiwar trilogy that he completed while being treated for cancer, died on April 10 in Tokyo. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Chile to Issue Coronavirus ‘Immunity Cards’ to Those Who Recover
description: The pandemic has reached Afghanistan’s presidential palace. Volunteers are stoking divisions as they tighten India’s lockdown.
content: Volunteer virus patrol squads are popping up across India. Neighborhoods are imposing extra rules and sealing themselves off. In rural areas, some carry sticks, sickles and pockets full of nails for puncturing the tires of cars they deem suspicious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Van Buren
title: What Is the Waldorf School Method?
description: The system of private schools is based on a philosophy that prioritizes the arts and the imagination.
content: This story was originally published on Aug. 15, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: What to Know About Montessori Preschools
description: They’re popular, but how do they differ from conventional nursery schools?
content: This story was originally published on Aug. 20, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 20, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Students
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Where Is Our Churchill?’
description: A reader looks for national leadership in the pandemic. Also: Food insecurity; scientific journals and the virus; helping museums document an important moment.
content: To the Editor:

title: Trump, Facing Criticism, Says He Will Increase Swab Production
description: Governors say reopening their economies must be linked with wider testing for the virus but they continue to face shortages of supplies and testing kits.
content: President Trump on Sunday said the administration was preparing to use the Defense Production Act to compel an unspecified U.S. facility to increase production of test swabs by over 20 million per month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Christian Yelich Is Trying ‘Not to Get Too Rusty’
description: The Milwaukee Brewers outfielder said he was still working out with baseball on hold. But learning how to cook? Nope, not yet.
content: People throughout the sports world, from athletes to arena staff, tell The New York Times how their lives have changed during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: That Face Shield Might Have Been Made in a Party Space
description: A chic loft in the meatpacking district has reinvented itself as a factory for personal protective equipment.
content: Last spring, Manhattan’s meatpacking district was hopping with stylish hotels, rooftop cocktail lounges, luxury boutiques, overpriced brunch spots and nightclubs with velvet ropes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Everyone’s Broke, and Relief Runs Dry
description: President Trump wants to reopen the economy, but health officials say we need rapid testing first.
content: What have you bought lately? Not much, I bet. Nonessentials seem beside the point right now, and the things we actually need are hard to find. I donned my mask and schlepped to three different stores to hunt down flour on Tuesday (success, finally, at a nearby bodega), but yeast? Forget about it. A record plunge in retail sales for March shows the bigger story. Here’s the latest business news, and what to know for the week ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Beyond ‘Trolls’ and ‘Frozen’: What Are Our Kids Listening To?
description: Children’s films lean heavily on pop, but the elementary school set has access to a whole universe of music now.
content: Now more than ever, children’s films lean heavily on pop music, whether in the form of original numbers or highly sweetened updates of well-known songs. “Frozen” and “Trolls” have resulted in albums that linger near the top of the charts and the occasional song — “Let It Go,” “Can’t Stop the Feeling!” — that oozes out from the world of children out into the collective popular consciousness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Trump Has Begun His Corona Campaign. We Don’t Have to Play Along.
description: The coronavirus story isn’t about the president.
content: Did you hear? The president said some things today. Mean things! About someone I know … I can’t quite remember the details, or whether it was today or yesterday, or what day of the week it is, anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Coronavirus, India’s Lockdown, Afghanistan: Your Monday Briefing
description: Let us help you start your day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $650,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Hobson
title: What Are Reggio Emilia Schools?
description: The educational philosophy born out of the ashes of World War II lacks the strictures of the typical North American classroom
content: This story was originally published on Aug. 16, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Pop Music Faces the Coronavirus in Prime Time
description: Lady Gaga, the Rolling Stones, Billie Eilish and more took over the major networks for a Global Citizen event celebrating essential workers and supporting the World Health Organization.
content: Songs called for inspiration, empathy and perseverance on “One World: Together at Home,” the prime-time special produced by Global Citizen that was broadcast Saturday night on CBS, NBC and ABC and online. Stephen Colbert, Jimmy Fallon and Jimmy Kimmel, late-night representatives from each network, were the hosts, toggling awkwardly between deadpan comedy and earnestness. Lady Gaga helped select the musical lineup, which included Billie Eilish, Lizzo, Taylor Swift, Stevie Wonder, Paul McCartney, Camila Cabello and Shawn Mendes, the Rolling Stones, Elton John and more — many more, since there was also a six-hour webcast before the televised broadcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry Berke
title: Impeachment Taught Trump All the Wrong Lessons
description: He thinks he can get away with anything.
content: Following the presentation of evidence in President Trump’s Senate trial, Senator Susan Collins argued that the president did not need to be removed from office because he has learned a “pretty big lesson” from his impeachment. The president did in fact learn lessons from his impeachment and acquittal, but all the wrong lessons, which he since has been applying in misleading the American people about the catastrophic pandemic, and exacerbating its devastating impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: In ‘Nerve,’ Facing Up to Fears With an Assist From Science
description: The journalist Eva Holland’s new book is an intimate and wide-ranging look at fears and trying to overcome them.
content: Eva Holland grew up “carrying, as most of us do, a quiver of assorted fears,” she writes in her new book, “Nerve: Adventures in the Science of Fear.” But chief among them was the fear of losing her mother. She felt confident that such a loss could be a “life-destroying force,” since she saw her mother still broken by the death of her own mother when she was a child. In “Nerve,” Holland also writes intimately about her fears of falling, of heights and, after she was involved in traumatic accidents, of driving. And she writes about the science behind those fears and the methods she and others have used to try to overcome them, including a therapy called E.M.D.R., or eye movement desensitization and reprocessing. Below, Holland talks about the scary day when she decided to write the book, the progress she made on her fears and how action movies have taught her some things about writing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Schiesel
title: Facebook to Introduce an App for Gaming
description: Video games are surging in popularity in the pandemic. So Facebook is rolling out an app designed for creating and watching live gameplay.
content: Facebook plans to introduce the Facebook Gaming mobile app on Monday, the social network said, in its most decisive move into the video game business as people seek entertainment during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Harnish
title: Fighting Vaccine Hesitancy, One Parent at a Time
description: Programs aim to counter anti-vaccine sentiments with parent-to-parent connections.
content: This story was originally published on Oct. 25, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Chavern
title: Google and Facebook Must Pay for Local Journalism
description: The U.S. should emulate the French government’s resolve to fight for the news media industry.
content: Much of the news business is being hammered by the decline in advertising because of Covid-19, just when the public most needs reliable information. While digital audiences are way up, the rapid contraction in revenue has so far caused 33,000 news media employees to be furloughed, to be laid off or to suffer reduced pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Lola Fadulu
title: Schools Transform Into ‘Relief’ Kitchens, but Federal Aid Fails to Keep Up
description: Many school cafeterias are now operating more like community soup kitchens, even though the federal school meals program won’t reimburse districts for meals served to struggling adults.
content: BALTIMORE — On the first day of the coronavirus school closure at Sinclair Lane Elementary School, Janet Bailey, the cafeteria manager, showed up to the school’s kitchen like any other day, ready to do her job. She began fixing the favorites of the 250 or so children who relied on her to feed them daily — chicken patties, a fruit and vegetable, and flavored milk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Suhasini Raj
title: Powered by Fear, Indians Embrace Coronavirus Lockdown
description: Volunteers set up their own roadblocks. Neighborhoods set their own limits. The efforts could help the fractious country battle the outbreak but risk also stoking divisions and xenophobia.
content: BHOND, India — On the long, straight road into the farming village of Bhond, past fields of tomatoes, eggplant and rust-colored wheat, stood a police barricade, an incongruous sight for a settlement so small and remote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Governors Plot Reopening the Economy but Say They Still Lack Tests
description: Democratic and Republican governors bristled at claims from the Trump administration that the supply of tests was adequate to move firmly toward reopening the country.
content: ATLANTA — Governors facing growing pressure to revive economies decimated by the coronavirus said on Sunday that a shortage of tests was among the most significant hurdles in the way of lifting restrictions in their states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Alan Rappeport
title: White House and Democrats Near Deal on Aid for Small Businesses
description: The $450 billion agreement would also include more money for hospitals and coronavirus testing, which Democrats had insisted on.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House and congressional Democrats on Sunday closed in on an agreement for a $450 billion economic relief package to replenish a depleted emergency fund for small businesses and to expand coronavirus testing around the country, with votes on the measure possible early this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Salcedo
title: He Went to 3 Hospitals. When He Finally Got a Bed, It Was Too Late.
description: Luis Arellano’s struggle to receive care illustrates the difficult decisions hospitals have to make in caring for coronavirus patients. They can mean the difference between life and death.
content: After feeling unwell with what seemed like symptoms of the coronavirus, Luis Arellano first tried going to a nearby hospital in Brooklyn, where he was told to come back if his condition worsened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: ‘Turn Around, Go Back’: Summer Islands Don’t Want Coronavirus, or You
description: With few medical resources to fight the virus, residents of the island havens east of New York City have fiercely protected their secluded hometowns.
content: Visitors to the western end of Fire Island are greeted by a large sign telling them to “Stop, turn around, go back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Ten Years After Deepwater Horizon, U.S. Is Still Vulnerable to Catastrophic Spills
description: Members of the bipartisan commission created to investigate the spill say Congress and the Trump administration have failed to take safety seriously.
content: WASHINGTON — Shortly before 10 p.m. on April 20, 2010, an explosion ripped through the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico, unleashing the worst offshore oil spill in United States history and triggering what were supposed to be systemic changes to ensure such a disaster could never happen again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
title: As Bolsonaro Keeps Amazon Vows, Brazil’s Indigenous Fear ‘Ethnocide’
description: President Jair Bolsonaro is moving aggressively to open up the Amazon rainforest to commercial development, posing an existential threat to the tribes living there.
content: URU EU WAU WAU TERRITORY, Brazil — The billboard at the entrance of a tiny Indigenous village in the Amazon has become a relic in less than a decade, boasting of something no longer true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Texas Bus Hijacking Leaves 2 Officers Wounded and Gunman Dead
description: The gunman, identified by authorities as Ramon Thomas Villagomez, was a suspect in a San Antonio murder.
content: A gunman hijacked a public bus in Texas on Sunday morning, prompting an hourlong police chase through several cities and a shootout that wounded two officers and killed the gunman, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Bars and Restaurants Peel Cash From Walls to Help Idled Workers
description: Owners are removing currency that had been stapled or taped inside their businesses to donate to employees affected by the coronavirus shutdown.
content: As stay-at-home orders took effect to slow the spread of the coronavirus, many restaurants and bars had to temporarily close or switch to delivery and takeout only, forcing owners to lay off or furlough employees.
source.name: The New York Times

title: De Blasio Pleads With Trump for Funding to Alleviate Virus Damage
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio compared President Trump to Gerald Ford and asked if he was telling New York City to ‘drop dead.’
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Sunday continued to call on President Trump to direct desperately-needed federal funding to American cities, and to criticize the president’s silence on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Eder, Megan Twohey and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Antibody Test, Seen as Key to Reopening Country, Does Not Yet Deliver
description: The tests, many made in China without F.D.A. approval, are often inaccurate. Some doctors are misusing them. The rollout is nowhere close to the demand.
content: A law firm in Scottsdale, Ariz., tested employees who hoped, with the prick of a finger, to learn if they might be immune. In Laredo, Texas, community leaders secured 20,000 of the new tests to gauge how many residents had been infected. In Chicago, a hospital screened firefighters to help determine whether they could safely stay on the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Franklin
title: Can’t Sleep? Let Stephen King Keep You Company
description: His latest book, the novella collection “If It Bleeds,” offers the familiar unsettling pleasures.
content: One night in the first weeks of the coronavirus pandemic, I found myself jolted awake at 2 o’clock in the morning, shaking with adrenaline and dread. Avoiding the call of my Twitter feed, I dragged myself from bed and cast an eye over my to-be-read pile. But nothing seemed right for this moment of uncertainty verging on unreality. Even my old favorites now seemed to come from another world. They weren’t speaking to a mind-set recalibrated by the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: The Woman Who Might Find Us Another Earth
description: The star-crossed life of Sara Seager, an astrophysicist obsessed with discovering the possibility of other life in the universe.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Oklahoma City Marks 25 Years Since America’s Deadliest Homegrown Attack
description: On the anniversary of the attack that killed 168 people, there is concern that the national memory is fading even as the violent ideology that inspired Timothy McVeigh spreads.
content: Timothy J. McVeigh slaughtered 168 people, including 19 children, by gutting a federal office building with a massive truck bomb on April 19, 1995, yet he features only fleetingly in the Oklahoma City National Memorial & Museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: Covid-19 Is the New Civil Rights Frontier
description: First came early data showing that the coronavirus affected African-Americans disproportionately. Then came the fight for a fair response and recovery.
content: Rallies and marches and other traditional forms of protest are out, given the social distancing restrictions now in place from coast to coast, but activists are organizing campaigns nonetheless aimed at what is emerging as the latest front in the country’s civil rights struggle: the disproportionate impact of the coronavirus on communities of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: ‘People Would Be So Receptive Right Now, and We Can’t Knock on Doors.’
description: The pandemic has put a stop to the activities of one of the nation’s most visible religious groups, Jehovah’s Witnesses.
content: Brenda Francis settled into the Kingdom Hall in Calhoun, Ga., in mid-March, surrounded by dozens of familiar faces. Signs cautioning against shaking hands and hugging were posted around the room. It felt weird to her but was certainly understandable with the threat of an outbreak looming. She herself already had stocked up on some masks and gloves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: Protesting for the Right to Catch the Coronavirus
description: The reopen America protests are the logical conclusion of a twisted liberty movement.
content: At a string of small “reopen America” protests across the country this week, mask-less citizens proudly flouted social distancing guidance while openly carrying semiautomatic rifles and waving American flags and signs with “ironic” swastikas. They organized chants to lock up female Democrat governors and to fire the country’s top infectious disease experts. At one point during protests at the Michigan Capitol, the group’s orchestrated gridlock blocked an ambulance en route to a nearby hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Franklin
title: Can’t Sleep? Let Stephen King Keep You Company
description: His latest book, the novella collection “If It Bleeds,” offers the familiar unsettling pleasures.
content: One night in the first weeks of the coronavirus pandemic, I found myself jolted awake at 2 o’clock in the morning, shaking with adrenaline and dread. Avoiding the call of my Twitter feed, I dragged myself from bed and cast an eye over my to-be-read pile. But nothing seemed right for this moment of uncertainty verging on unreality. Even my old favorites now seemed to come from another world. They weren’t speaking to a mind-set recalibrated by the crisis.

title: How an Invisible Foe Slipped Aboard a French Navy Ship
description: Nearly 60 percent of sailors from the flagship aircraft carrier, the Charles de Gaulle, tested positive for Covid-19, leading to questions, finger-pointing and investigations.
content: PARIS — In January, France’s prime minister addressed sailors aboard the country’s only aircraft carrier, the Charles de Gaulle, and extolled the vessel as a crown jewel in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Riff on recipes, whether it’s a five-ingredient creamy miso pasta with five other ingredients, or a Dutch baby that gets its rise from sourdough starter.
content: Good morning. The waffles were different this morning, the sourdough sponge a little denser than yesterday’s, as yesterday’s was looser than the one from the day before. The ingredients and measurements remain the same each day, but they react to the yeast and the lactobaccili in the starter in singular ways, every time. There’s something emotionally helpful about that for anyone housebound and prone to dark moods, this chance to observe dough and therefore life as a farmer does her fields each morning, as a clammer does his patch of water and mud. There’s wonder everywhere, if only you look for it. Look for it. It might be in a tree outside your window, in the patch of sky you can see if you crane your neck, in the herbs you’re growing, in the nest the swans are building on that open stretch of marsh across the street. Beats sulking.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wyoming Caucus Election Results 2020
description: Detailed results and maps from the Wyoming presidential caucus election.
content: Detailed results and maps from the Wyoming presidential caucus election.

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘The Last Dance’ and ‘Bosch’
description: A documentary series on Michael Jordan’s final run with the Chicago Bulls debuts on ESPN, while a new season of “Bosch” streams on Amazon.
content: THE LAST DANCE 9 p.m. on ESPN. This has been a stressful year, so why not revisit happier times, such as, say, when Michael Jordan was playing with the Chicago Bulls? This 10-part documentary series was shot during the 1997-1998 season, when Jordan won his sixth and final title with the team. The show traces his career, before and after he became a force to be reckoned with on the court, and examines the triumphs and behind-the-scenes flare-ups during the heyday of the Bulls. It also gives considerable screen time to Jordan’s teammates Scottie Pippen and Dennis Rodman, and head coach, Phil Jackson. A number of big names weigh in, including Bill Clinton, Justin Timberlake and Barack Obama. The series debuts on April 19 with two episodes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Latest on the Children Affected by the Crisis at the Southern Border

title: For Charlie Kirk, Conservative Activist, the Virus Is a Cudgel
description: Mixing, matching and twisting facts about the coronavirus online, Mr. Kirk has created a template for a new kind of political agitator.
content: WASHINGTON — Shortly before midnight on Friday, and just hours after he had taken to Twitter to encourage Americans to “liberate” three Democratic-governed states from stay-at-home orders, President Trump reopened his Twitter app and went on another brief tear. He retweeted 11 posts by Charlie Kirk, a young right-wing provocateur with ties to the Trump family and a social media presence that attracts far more attention than some mainstream news organizations.

title: 2 Georgia High Schoolers Posted Racist Video, Officials Say
description: The two are “no longer students” in the Carrollton, Ga., district, the superintendent said. Their video, posted on TikTok on Thursday, has been viewed millions of times across social media platforms.
content: The video shows two high school students, a boy and a girl, standing in front of a bathroom mirror. The camera pans to a racial slur written on a piece of paper in the sink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Fairyington
title: 6 Things That Drive Day Care Workers Crazy
description: Here’s what you can do to make a caregiver’s life easier, and improve things for your family.
content: This story was originally published on Aug. 13, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Don’t Mention the Virus! And Other Marketing Tips
description: Brands and influencers want to sell products to homebound customers, but doing so requires being sensitive to the reality of the pandemic.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic moved across the United States, the stock market plunged and many of the country’s businesses closed, a major platform for social media influencers had a rosier message: “Good news in consumer shopping trends!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Hollywood’s Backstage Creatives Try to Soldier On
description: Production has ground to a halt, leaving a vast number of people without work and others trying to figure out how to finish projects remotely.
content: LOS ANGELES — Just a few weeks ago, Hollywood’s global assembly lines were spinning at full speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Fahim Abed
title: Dozens Test Positive for Coronavirus at Afghan President’s Palace
description: There’s no evidence that President Ashraf Ghani is infected, but the pandemic’s reach into the seat of power further tests war-torn Afghanistan.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — At least 40 staff members in Afghanistan’s presidential palace have tested positive for Covid-19, Afghan officials said on Sunday, forcing President Ashraf Ghani to isolate himself and manage the country’s response to the virus — amid a raging war — largely via video conference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Where a Nuthatch Hatches
description: Lynn Lempel opens our solving week with a “Wow!”
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Lynn Lempel returns, and she’s just gobsmacked, but hopefully in a good way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Calderone
title: 10 Years of Fertility Advances
description: How a decade of major discoveries has dramatically changed how we think about conception.
content: This article was originally published on December 11, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mira Ptacin
title: How to Stay Married After Losing a Baby
description: The pain of pregnancy loss lingers and can take a toll on your relationship.
content: This essay was originally published on February 18, 2020 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacey Stowe
title: Peter Beard’s Family Confirms His Death
description: The police were leading an extensive search for Mr. Beard, an artist who disappeared on Long Island on March 31.
content: The family of Peter Beard, the artist and wildlife photographer who disappeared last month from his ocean bluff property on Long Island’s East End, said that a body found on Sunday in Montauk was Mr. Beard’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin, Scott Reyburn and Zachary Small
title: Auction Houses Postpone Live Sales and Pivot to Online
description: In response to Covid-19, Sotheby’s, Christie’s and Phillips are stepping up digital selling, but the prices don’t yet come close to those in the auction room.
content: Francis Bacon’s 1981 three-part oil painting, “Triptych Inspired by the Oresteia of Aeschylus,” was supposed to feature in Sotheby’s marquee contemporary art evening auction in New York on May 13, where it was estimated to sell for at least $60 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mira Ptacin
title: How to Stay Married After Losing a Baby
description: The pain of pregnancy loss lingers and can take a toll on your relationship.
content: This essay was originally published on February 18, 2020 in NYT Parenting.

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ‘My Last Stand’: In South Korea, a Protester’s Lone Fight Against Samsung
description: Kim Yong-hee has been ​staging sit-ins and hunger strikes at the top of an 82-foot-tall traffic camera tower overlooking the busiest intersection in Seoul — for more than 300 days and counting.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — Overlooking the busiest intersection in Seoul is an 82-foot traffic camera tower. At the top is Kim Yong-hee, a 60-year-old man with a sleeping bag, plastic sheeting and placards denouncing Samsung, South Korea’s most powerful conglomerate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise and Sarah Mervosh
title: America’s Biggest Cities Were Already Losing Their Allure. What Happens Next?
description: The urge among some residents to leave because of the coronavirus may be temporary. But it follows a deeper, more powerful demographic trend.
content: Even before the coronavirus, Nina Brajovic wasn’t so sure about her life in New York. As a consultant for PricewaterhouseCoopers, she spent most weeks out of town traveling for work. She often wondered whether she could do her same job for cheaper — and more easily — while based in her hometown, Pittsburgh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Noriko Hayashi
title: Tokyo, in a State of Emergency, Yet Still Having Drinks at a Bar
description: Tokyo may have been lulled into complacency during the weeks when Japan contained the coronavirus while avoiding economically devastating lockdowns, our bureau chief writes.
content: TOKYO — It was a scene of normalcy, something friends in New York or London or San Francisco can only conjure in memory: a man and a woman, out for a drink.
source.name: The New York Times
